componenttextpreview: You have a follow-on, Amit?
componenttext: You have a follow-on, Amit?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Yes, if I could just follow-up. OpEx, I guess, at least in the June quarter, it was higher-than-expected. Sort of comparable to what happened in the March quarter, if I'm not mistaken, can you just talk about how do you look at OpEx as a percent o
componenttext: Got it. Yes, if I could just follow-up. OpEx, I guess, at least in the June quarter, it was higher-than-expected. Sort of comparable to what happened in the March quarter, if I'm not mistaken, can you just talk about how do you look at OpEx as a percent of sale, and what's driving the higher uptick there, it sounds looks like it's more R&D than anything in the first half of the year so far.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm not so sure, Amit, if it was higher-than-expected per se, but it was certainly higher than it was last quarter, and higher on a year-over-year basis. We've got a couple of things going on there. Sequentially, you got 3, 4 months worth of payment
componenttext: Yes. I'm not so sure, Amit, if it was higher-than-expected per se, but it was certainly higher than it was last quarter, and higher on a year-over-year basis. We've got a couple of things going on there. Sequentially, you got 3, 4 months worth of payment and debt increases, so that's a quarter we only had 2 months worth. That's also true year-over-year by the way, we've just got payment increases. But also importantly on the R&D as you noted, we have been for a number of quarters now, we allocated in our internal resources towards more development efforts. So those will be resources that may have been working and manufacturing support. They may have been working in SG&A. And we're redeploying those resources into development activity and R&D. And we expect to continue doing that for a number of quarters to come. And so consequently, you're seeing R&D begin to move up a little bit more than what you might see on the G&A line.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll be C.J. Muse with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Next we'll be C.J. Muse with Evercore ISI.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the question to go back to your incremental gross margins and try it may be take a little bit deeper and may be understanding how much is going up the G&A mix utilization, the benefit of 300-millimeter. So if you look at calendar '16, things play
componenttext: I guess, the question to go back to your incremental gross margins and try it may be take a little bit deeper and may be understanding how much is going up the G&A mix utilization, the benefit of 300-millimeter. So if you look at calendar '16, things play out seasonal. It looks like $150 million benefit from D&A, but another $200 million from these other categories. Is there any way to parse that out and then better understand and go forward, what that might look like for each of those categories in next utilization [indiscernible]?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, C.J. Just to think about that from an underutilization, in fact there's no real benefit That's going on there. The underutilization cost are almost exactly the same for multiple quarters in a row now. Depreciation has actually come down, so you compa
componenttext: Yes, C.J. Just to think about that from an underutilization, in fact there's no real benefit That's going on there. The underutilization cost are almost exactly the same for multiple quarters in a row now. Depreciation has actually come down, so you compare the most recent quarter to $155 million of depreciation. The year-ago quarter was $198 million. So you get about $45 million depreciation, and really the rest of it is just lower overall manufacturing costs. And again, incrementally, we're getting more production on 300-millimeter, which at that dye level has a 40% cost benefit for us. So that's an overall 20% improvement to gross profit margin on -- or excuse me, 20 -- case growth profit margin up effectively because cost comes down that bought them out. So you got the combination of all of those things, laying in together. So again, depreciation down about $45 million, 2Q to 2Q on a year-over-year basis, underutilization charge is pretty flat throughout that period. So it was really a conversion to lower-cost manufacturing.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And just, I'll just add for those that may not follow us as closely why 300-millimeter makes the difference. So  we've got a footprint manufacturing Analog products at 200-millimeter. And the 300-millimeter we ended last year with about $6 billion
componenttext: Right. And just, I'll just add for those that may not follow us as closely why 300-millimeter makes the difference. So  we've got a footprint manufacturing Analog products at 200-millimeter. And the 300-millimeter we ended last year with about $6 billion of open capacity on 300-millimeter. And the wafer size is bigger and that translate into a lower-cost as Kevin was talking about, at the chip level and the silicon level, it's 40% lower. So basically, as we build more of our products on 300-millimeter, that will help to drive gross margin as well at free cash flow. So C.J., you have a follow-up question?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. That was very helpful. If I could just ask a short-term question. In terms of gross margin in September, will mix be a headwind there or should we say gross margins at least flat?
componenttext: Yes, Dave. That was very helpful. If I could just ask a short-term question. In terms of gross margin in September, will mix be a headwind there or should we say gross margins at least flat?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: C.J., I don't think that mix is going to really play too much a factor on this. We're going to continue to have more production on 300-millimeter in the lower manufacturing cost and its really just the economics that Dave just mentioned, that's going to k
componenttext: C.J., I don't think that mix is going to really play too much a factor on this. We're going to continue to have more production on 300-millimeter in the lower manufacturing cost and its really just the economics that Dave just mentioned, that's going to keep helping on gross margin going forward.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could give us an update on the Embedded Processing segment. You're showing some nice growth there. Can you talk about where that's coming from? And in particular the previous Wireless business OMAP kind of activity, can you talk about the
componenttext: I wonder if you could give us an update on the Embedded Processing segment. You're showing some nice growth there. Can you talk about where that's coming from? And in particular the previous Wireless business OMAP kind of activity, can you talk about the growth that you might be seeing there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Joe. So year-over-year as we had said before, we're seeing good growth in all 3 product lines. And just as a reminder. For 2015, we had 3 product lines inside of Embedded. Microcontrollers, which made up 45% of revenue processors. Again, 45% in
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Joe. So year-over-year as we had said before, we're seeing good growth in all 3 product lines. And just as a reminder. For 2015, we had 3 product lines inside of Embedded. Microcontrollers, which made up 45% of revenue processors. Again, 45% in Connectivity at 10%. So I'll just say over the last few years, Connectivity has been growing very strongly, though it's coming obviously, from a much lower revenue base. And they're -- we support a dozen or so connectivity standards. And those products are finding -- I'll just say very, very diverse, different applications and doing very nicely. Processors again, is doing very well. It is being benefited from both automotive as well as recovery that we saw inside of comms infrastructure. And then Microcontrollers is benefiting from really, the industrial market as its finding very, very diverse application. So that's kind of what that looks like across the board. Do you have a follow on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's very helpful. Just secondly, I wonder if there any areas where you're seeing tighter availability or lead time extensions or anything like that across the whole portfolio?
componenttext: Yes. That's very helpful. Just secondly, I wonder if there any areas where you're seeing tighter availability or lead time extensions or anything like that across the whole portfolio?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd say that across the border, our lead times have remain unchanged and at very, very low levels. So product availability continues to be very good. And both of our distributors as well as for the products that we support through consignment program
componenttext: Yes. I'd say that across the border, our lead times have remain unchanged and at very, very low levels. So product availability continues to be very good. And both of our distributors as well as for the products that we support through consignment programs or in a classical book ship business. So really, no changes on that. And I'll just also mentioned that just our on-time delivery. So kind of our metrics, the customers want to have them, remain at very, very high level.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that question will come from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.
componenttext: And that question will come from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin and Dave, I wanted to follow-up follow up on Embedded Processing operating margins for the last couple of years, the company has had the objective to get them higher. And you've done a lot on the OpEx side now, for a second consecutive quarter we're
componenttext: Kevin and Dave, I wanted to follow-up follow up on Embedded Processing operating margins for the last couple of years, the company has had the objective to get them higher. And you've done a lot on the OpEx side now, for a second consecutive quarter we're in the mid-20s. Can you put in context where operating margins are now versus I think levels that the company would be happy with. Is it possible to get to Analog levels? Or are we at optimal levels now with EP?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Craig, on that, I would say that there's nothing inherently different between the Analog and Embedded. I'll point you to say why the margins would be different. What I would say is that while we'll try to predict the margins in the individual segments
componenttext: So Craig, on that, I would say that there's nothing inherently different between the Analog and Embedded. I'll point you to say why the margins would be different. What I would say is that while we'll try to predict the margins in the individual segments per se, we're confident that Embedded Processing just like Analog can be a very solid contributor to the free cash flow growth over the long haul, and again, this is larger because the products that we manufacture in that segment have very low market shelf lives. So you can get to the -- you may recall that over the last couple of years, and in kind of early last year, where we were doing some restructuring activity in Embedded Processing and taking some cost out. And we've been talking for a while now that the real secret to be able to improve the profitability in that area was on revenue growth. And that team has been doing a very good job at turning the results of their efforts into solid revenue growth. And consequently, we're seeing the profitability go up. They are committed to continuing in that direction so I look forward to see what they as we build multiple quarters up.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow on, Craig?
componenttext: Do you have a follow on, Craig?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the follow-up is related to Chris' question. You mentioned that the performance of the business was just a little bit better than expected on a broad basis in the second quarter. Was that because the order strength of the business was just better tha
componenttext: Yes, the follow-up is related to Chris' question. You mentioned that the performance of the business was just a little bit better than expected on a broad basis in the second quarter. Was that because the order strength of the business was just better than the teams going into the quarter? Or wasn't that the business just scoped a little bit more conservatively than it played out? What accounted for the upside versus expectations?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I would just point to that -- we've got 55% of our revenue that runs through consignment. So we actually don't get orders there. We get forecasts that get pulled actual demand. We got 60% of our revenues that run through distribution and 60% of th
componenttext: Yes. So I would just point to that -- we've got 55% of our revenue that runs through consignment. So we actually don't get orders there. We get forecasts that get pulled actual demand. We got 60% of our revenues that run through distribution and 60% of that is actually on consignment. So our -- what we shipped, the demand that we ship to is much closer to real-time of what customers want and need. So I think that very simplistically, they just ended up pulling more -- slightly more than what we were initially expecting across a broad range. So if there's something in there that we could point to 1 or 2 things, we would do that. But that's just not the case this time.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll go to John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the strong, consistent results. Kevin, I wanted to talk a little bit about OpEx patterns into the calendar third quarter. For the last kind of 3 years, you've had good sequential revenue growth in the calendar third quarter of about 6%.
componenttext: Congratulations on the strong, consistent results. Kevin, I wanted to talk a little bit about OpEx patterns into the calendar third quarter. For the last kind of 3 years, you've had good sequential revenue growth in the calendar third quarter of about 6%. And you've been able to take OpEx down on average by about 3%, sequentially. So I'm just kind of curious. Is there a seasonal pattern to OpEx that we should think about for the calendar third quarter in general? And specifically, how do you see OpEx trending this September?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. I think you said it well in that, you do see some patterns similar to the numbers you just cited. Typically, you'll see SG&A and R&D down a bit in the third versus the second. Part of that is people taking vacations on the summer holidays, but
componenttext: Yes, John. I think you said it well in that, you do see some patterns similar to the numbers you just cited. Typically, you'll see SG&A and R&D down a bit in the third versus the second. Part of that is people taking vacations on the summer holidays, but I think this quarter, you'll continue to see that sort of trend probably in the SG&A area. But I would expect that R&D would continue to increase a little bit as we move forward, dampening the overall decline that you might expect in OpEx. And that again has to do with what I mentioned earlier in the call. That's for a number of quarters now, we have been deploying resources into development activities and those costs are one and up in R&D as we deploy those resources. So I was looking to third quarter. Again, you're probably going to see that G&A will probably be down a little bit, but R&D will probably be up some.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's helpful. A follow-on guys, one of the things you guys have always sort of talked about was the consistency of growth here, and not necessarily absolute growth. Albeit, you talked about sort of modest share gain expectations every year. And just
componenttext: And that's helpful. A follow-on guys, one of the things you guys have always sort of talked about was the consistency of growth here, and not necessarily absolute growth. Albeit, you talked about sort of modest share gain expectations every year. And just when I look at the Embedded Processing growth of over 9% year-over-year. To me, that clearly is sort of outgrowing the industry and the peers. And so I'm just kind of curious, what you think the cause of that is? How sustainable that is? And kind of should we expect to see continued market share growth within the Embedded segment of these sort of clips?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. We'll finish the year before we declare any victory laps on market share gains. And I'll just say that if you look at that business as well as Analog, we just had steady share gains. And we've talked about averaging between 30 and 40 basis poin
componenttext: Yes, John. We'll finish the year before we declare any victory laps on market share gains. And I'll just say that if you look at that business as well as Analog, we just had steady share gains. And we've talked about averaging between 30 and 40 basis points per year. But we've had years where we've put up 100 basis point gains in the past. So again, we don't want to get ahead of where the year will end. We'll wait till the scoreboard is up before we analyze that. But we -- I'd just say that we continue to focus our resources in places where we can develop products that are going to be differentiated. They're are going to find a long-lived position in the marketplace. And when you're able to do that, you're able to have a revenue stream in which you're able to build on. And the great thing about these -- both these markets is that share gain doesn't move quickly. And so, but it does -- it's a steady share gains over time will make a significant difference to the business model. And we think that, that is certainly showing up in the numbers today.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Caso with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Caso with CLSA.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to start with kind of a bigger picture question. You talked about some of the forecast visibility from your consignment revenue. Can you talk a little bit about how far out that goes? And what the order patterns are telling you? And then correspondin
componenttext: Just to start with kind of a bigger picture question. You talked about some of the forecast visibility from your consignment revenue. Can you talk a little bit about how far out that goes? And what the order patterns are telling you? And then correspondingly, what have you seen with regard to order rates over the last 9 days as compared to the previous quarter? Are they fairly stable? Improving or declining?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Chris, it'll depend on the customer or distributor. I'd say that typically, will get looked out on demand out for 6 months. Sometimes it'll be longer and we'll get a longer term forecast run, but usually, they run about 6 months. Inside of a certa
componenttext: Yes. So Chris, it'll depend on the customer or distributor. I'd say that typically, will get looked out on demand out for 6 months. Sometimes it'll be longer and we'll get a longer term forecast run, but usually, they run about 6 months. Inside of a certain window, those forecasts are deemed as more firm. But that said, they can change and they can change very quickly. So we can have 100% visibility, but that doesn't that those forecasts can't change. From an order standpoint, I can tell you that during the quarter, we saw orders were higher in May. They increased again in June. That's kind of what happened in the second quarter. And I'd just say that those order rates versus when we were all in the book ship business without a consignment, certainly we're a different than what they are today. We look at those -- the orders that we have on the books. We look at the consignment forecast that we see and we make judgments based on that and roll that up to what we provide to you in our outlook. So do you have a follow on, Chris?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. With regard to inventory. It looks like it was down sequentially in days. But I believe it's was towards the higher end of your range. Can you talk about your expectations? I suppose that you would expect that to drop as you go in the second half? Do
componenttext: Yes. With regard to inventory. It looks like it was down sequentially in days. But I believe it's was towards the higher end of your range. Can you talk about your expectations? I suppose that you would expect that to drop as you go in the second half? Do you have a particular target in mind for where you'd expect inventory to approach as we exit the year? And what that applies for production in the second half? I know you try to level of production given the seasonality if that were the case this year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris. I don't really have a specific inventory forecast for you per se. I would just point out a couple of things on inventory to kind of keep in mind. Total dollars of inventory are actually down on a year-over-year basis even though days are up. A
componenttext: Yes, Chris. I don't really have a specific inventory forecast for you per se. I would just point out a couple of things on inventory to kind of keep in mind. Total dollars of inventory are actually down on a year-over-year basis even though days are up. And that's really a function of the higher profitability that the company's performing at now, and just do the math and a higher gross margin percent, that same inventory and 4 [ph] more days of potential sales, so that's part of what's going on there. But as you noted, it is down quarter-over-quarter on a day's basis. And typically going into the third quarter, it typically tends to be an up revenue quarter for us. And as you mentioned, when we leveled off the factories, that would anticipate that some of the inventory will be drained as we go through the quarter. But we don't have a specific forecast as today's dollars, we just is expect the upcoming green somewhat going into the third quarter. And then we'll continue to adjust our loadings and our expectation for first and fourth quarter, as we continue through the year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Blayne Curtis with Barclays is next.
componenttext: And Blayne Curtis with Barclays is next.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good execution. I just wanted to follow back upon a prior OpEx question, it's just how do you think about managing it? Obviously, you've gotten the question why R&D as a percentage of revenue as well, and the bottom in '15 [ph], you've grown it faster tha
componenttext: Good execution. I just wanted to follow back upon a prior OpEx question, it's just how do you think about managing it? Obviously, you've gotten the question why R&D as a percentage of revenue as well, and the bottom in '15 [ph], you've grown it faster than revenues, how do you think about it over the next year or 2 going forward? Is there a particular percentage you're managing it to? Or is it a function of where you can get gross margins and how you're thinking about it? And then if you could just talk about where you're deploying these new resources.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Blayne. So just kind of first, the 50,000-foot level. We've talked about our total OpEx will probably fluctuate between 20% and 30% of revenue. Meaning that in weaker markets we're at the higher end of that range, stronger markets will run at the lo
componenttext: Okay, Blayne. So just kind of first, the 50,000-foot level. We've talked about our total OpEx will probably fluctuate between 20% and 30% of revenue. Meaning that in weaker markets we're at the higher end of that range, stronger markets will run at the lower end of that range. Again the last couple of years, we're around the middle of that pack we're around 23%, 24%, 25% kind of range, so that's kind of a high level looking OpEx as a whole and more specifically on R&D. When it comes to allocating capital and R&D is certainly a place where we allocate some of that capital, so it's a pretty important thing for any management to pay attention to, we take it extremely seriously that when we do allocate to R&D, we allocate in areas that we believe that we can actually developed differentiated products with very long revenue streams and very high margin opportunities. Now the idea is to maximize the amount of revenue we get on R&D dollars spent. So it's not a percent per se that we're trying to manage to. It's an opportunity that we're going after. And as we just talked about earlier in the call, some of our R&D spending is actually moving up a little bit even in this past few quarters and will probably move up to the next few quarters as we see opportunities to reallocate some of our resources from where they have been into development areas for are in the purposes that will just extend the overall availability of our products and the new marketplace. So we're really looking at opportunistically and not based upon a particular model or percent of revenue or anything like that.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow on, Blayne?
componenttext: Do you have a follow on, Blayne?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just switching gears to the auto market. There's been concerns all year, but I think the data point has been stronger than not. Just curious your perspective on that market as you go into September in terms of inventory, and the strength you saw wit
componenttext: Maybe just switching gears to the auto market. There's been concerns all year, but I think the data point has been stronger than not. Just curious your perspective on that market as you go into September in terms of inventory, and the strength you saw with that for a function of units or was it more complicated answer?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Clearly, what's driving the market today, we believe, is content gains. So if you have visited the auto show room anytime in the last year, that's pretty obvious to see when the new models that are coming out. Our belief is that automotive sales will
componenttext: Yes. Clearly, what's driving the market today, we believe, is content gains. So if you have visited the auto show room anytime in the last year, that's pretty obvious to see when the new models that are coming out. Our belief is that automotive sales will fluctuate much like they have in the past and into the future. But certainly, that over all the content gain is what's growing these things. So as Kevin said, when we look at the automotive market, we're making investments that will produce revenue 5 and 10 and 15 years out into the future. If things were to weaken in that market and we don't know if that's going to be next quarter or 5 years from now when that does, but we know how to handle those types of situations tactically, but it won't really change our investment levels and what we believe will be the drivers for our business and really the industry in the next 5 or 10 years. So I hope that helps, Blayne.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And that question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question on your Embedded versus Analog margins. I'm curious how much of that Delta is that the gross margin level or how much is it OpEx intensity level? And if it's a gross margin level, what levers do you have? Is it just that you can move a g
componenttext: I have a question on your Embedded versus Analog margins. I'm curious how much of that Delta is that the gross margin level or how much is it OpEx intensity level? And if it's a gross margin level, what levers do you have? Is it just that you can move a greater proportion of these products the 300-millimeter? Or I'm just trying to get a sense for how much improvement you can make and Embedded margins without necessarily depending on sales growth.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vivek. I would say, we disclose for by segment the revenue and the operating profit and we don't dig into too many details underneath that as to what's happening between the lines. I would say that the -- at the gross margin level, obviously, it does
componenttext: Yes, Vivek. I would say, we disclose for by segment the revenue and the operating profit and we don't dig into too many details underneath that as to what's happening between the lines. I would say that the -- at the gross margin level, obviously, it does benefit from our continued efforts to lower our manufacturing costs. So that's clearly happening there from an OpEx standpoint. We have been reducing a couple of years up through about May of last year. We've got that OpEx down mostly at the level that we want that. So it really is a question of being able to drive revenue growth and leverage off of the OpEx that we have and that leverage then falls straight through to free cash flow, which is a direct benefit of course, to our shareholders based upon the performance the we talked about capital management. So that's how we tend to look at it as opposed to trying to force a model out of it, the 2 segments being comparable. We look at what they can actually generate online.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-on, Vivek?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-on, Vivek?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Maybe you can help us quantify how much of your Analog sales are on 300-millimeter now and how much of your Embedded sales are on 300-millimeter?
componenttext: Yes. Maybe you can help us quantify how much of your Analog sales are on 300-millimeter now and how much of your Embedded sales are on 300-millimeter?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vivek. We talked about in our capital management call that we ended last year with about $2 billion of our Analog revenue, which were roughly about $8 billion [ph] in that year on 300-millimeter. So approximately 25% of revenue. I will say that when
componenttext: Yes, Vivek. We talked about in our capital management call that we ended last year with about $2 billion of our Analog revenue, which were roughly about $8 billion [ph] in that year on 300-millimeter. So approximately 25% of revenue. I will say that when you look at that factory where we're building it, we call it our Richardson fab or our fab for short, that will support $5 billion of revenue when it's completely full. And if you look at that $5 billion, 1 of the reasons why we believe that our manufacturing and technology is one of the competitive advantages that we've got is because that $5 billion is significantly larger than any of our Analog competitors that we've got. So that level of scale just doesn't makes sense for them. And beyond our fab, we've got and qualified our second 300-millimeter factory that we creatively called DMOS6, which is a little less than a mile from the office that we're currently in. So I can say that we did qualify that at the end of last year as we were anticipating. And we have revenue-generating wafers that are running through that factory today. So will update next year on our capital management call where we stand on that overall utilization, our intent is to build more products inside of there. But we'll wait for them to update it.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: Well, I would just say Tore over all, I think that we've -- we're operating at a similar macro environment do what we've seen in actually recent years. I think the benefit of us having a consignment and having consignment the distribution is our revenues more close match that demand. That doesn't mean that they can't change quickly in the future at some point. But certainly, we're shipping what we believe -- what we've know for sure for that portion of demand is those shipments was very, very close to actual demand and consumption. So thank you, Tore. headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to Texas Instruments 2Q '16 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to Texas Instruments 2Q '16 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today. For any of you who missed the release,  you can find it on our website at ti.co
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today. 
For any of you who missed the release,  you can find it on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through our website. A replay will be available through the web. 
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description. 
I'll start with a quick summary. Revenue and earnings per share for the quarter were solidly in the upper half of our for expected range. Compared with a year ago, demand for our products continue to be strong in the automotive market and grew in industrial and communications equipment market. Despite sequential growth, demand in the personal electronics market was down from a year ago. 
In our 4 businesses, Embedded Processing revenue grew 9%, and Analog revenue was about even with the same quarter a year ago. Operating margins increased in both businesses. Earnings per share were $0.76. With that backdrop, Kevin and I will move on to the details of our performance, which we believe continues to be representative of the ongoing strength of our business model. 
In the second quarter, our cash flow from operations was $1.1 billion. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long-term. Free cash flow for the trailing 12-month period was $3.9 billion, up 7% from a year ago. Free cash flow margin was 30% of revenue, up from 27.4% a year ago. 
We continue to benefit from our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, the latter of which includes our growing 300-millimeter Analog output and the opportunistic purchase of assets ahead of demand. We believe that free cash flow will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. 
For the trailing 12-month period, we returned $4.1 billion of cash to investors through a combination of dividends and stock repurchases. From a year ago, Analog revenue was about even with growth in High Performance Analog and Silicon Valley set by declines in High Volume Analog & Logic and Power Management. 
Embedded Processing revenue increased by 9% from a year ago due to growth in all 3 product line led by processors. Our investments in Embedded continue to build a diverse business of long-lived products that contribute to free cash flow growth over the long-term. 
In our Other segment. Revenue declined 4% from a year ago due to calculators, royalties and custom ASIC products, which was partially offset by DLP products. 
Now I'll move to provide some insight into this quarter's revenue performance by end market versus a year ago. Automotive demand remained strong with the majority of sectors growing led by infotainment. Industrial demand had broad-based growth, with more than half of the sectors growing. Personal electronics declined broadly led by mobile phone. Communications equipment grew from a year ago but declined sequentially. And finally, enterprise systems grew.
We continue to focus on making our company stronger through manufacturing and technology, the breadth of our product portfolio, the reach of our market channels and our diverse and long-lived position. These 4 attributes, taken together, are at the core of what puts TI in a unique class of companies capable of long-term free cash flow growth. 
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $2.0 billion or 61.2% of revenue. From a year ago, gross profit margin increased 300 basis points primarily due to lower manufacturing costs. Operating expenses were $805 million,
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $2.0 billion or 61.2% of revenue. From a year ago, gross profit margin increased 300 basis points primarily due to lower manufacturing costs. Operating expenses were $805 million, up 2% from a year ago. Over the last 12 months, we've invested $1.29 billion on research and development, an important element of our capital allocation. 
Acquisition charges were $79 million, all of which for the ongoing amortization of intangibles, which is a noncash expense. Operating profit was $1.12 billion or 34.1% of revenue. Operating profit was up 11% from the year-ago quarter. Operating margin for Analog was 37.7%, and for Embedded Processing was 25.0%. Our focus investments on the best sustainable growth opportunities with differentiated positions enable both businesses to continue to contribute nicely to free cash flow growth. Net income in the second quarter was $779 million or $0.76 per share. 
Now let me comment on our capital management results starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $1.07 billion in the quarter. Inventory days are 133, consistent with our long-term model of 105 to 135 days as we staged inventory for expected revenue growth in the third quarter. Capital expenditures were $158 million in the quarter. On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow from operations was $4.46 billion, up 9% in the same period a year ago. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $585 million or 4.5% of revenue. 
As a reminder, our long-term expectations is for capital expenditures, including the expansion of our 300-millimeter Analog capacity, to be about 4% of revenue. 
Free cash flow for the past 12 months was $3.87 billion or 30.0% of revenue. Free cash flow was 7% higher than a year ago. Our cash flow reflects the strength of our business model. As we've said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long-term and will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively reinvested into the business. 
As we've noted, our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive in the exercise of equity compensation minus net debt retirement. 
For those who may have missed it. In May, we issued $500 million of 6-year debt at a coupon rate of 1.85%. In addition, we have retired $1 billion of debt. This leaves total debt of $3.63 billion with a weighted average coupon rate of 2.22%. 
In the second quarter, we paid $382 million in dividends and repurchased $527 million of our stock for a total return of $909 million. Total cash returned to shareholders in the past 12 months was $4.07 billion. 
Outstanding share count was reduced by 3% over the past 12 months and by 42% since the end of 2004 when we initiated a program designed to reduce our share count. These combined returns demonstrate our confidence in our business model and our commitments to return excess cash to our shareholders. 
Fundamental to our equipment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the second quarter with $2.54 billion of cash and short-term investments with our U.S. entities owning about 80% of our cash. This onshore cash is readily available for a variety of uses. Our orders in the quarter were $3.33 billion, up 2% from a year ago. 
Turning to our outlook. For the third quarter, we expect revenue in the range of $3.34 billion to $3.62 billion, and earnings per share to be in the range of $0.81 to $0.91. Acquisition charges, which are noncash amortization charges, will remain about even and hold at about $80 million per quarter through the third quarter of 2019. They will then decline to about $50 million per quarter for 2 additional years. Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2016 is unchanged at about 30%, and this is the tax rate you should use for the first quarter and for the year. 
In summary, we believe our second quarter results demonstrate the strength of our business model. With that, let me turn it back to Dave.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Can you give us some idea of gross margin drivers in the quarter? It seems like gross margins came in a little stronger. And how do you see those drivers trending into next year? Do you think gross margin should be up on the higher revenues?
componenttext: Yes. Can you give us some idea of gross margin drivers in the quarter? It seems like gross margins came in a little stronger. And how do you see those drivers trending into next year? Do you think gross margin should be up on the higher revenues?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Stacy, the drivers to gross margin are -- last quarter and going in for the forseeable future is, the same thing that we've been seeing for a while, and that is, we're seeing depreciation rolling off, which just clearly have given us accounting benef
componenttext:
Yes. Stacy, the drivers to gross margin are -- last quarter and going in for the forseeable future is, the same thing that we've been seeing for a while, and that is, we're seeing depreciation rolling off, which just clearly have given us accounting benefit to gross margin. But more importantly, we've got increased production on 300-millimeter, which is considerably more cost-effective on a chip level than the equivalent 200-millimeter production. And as we see depreciation continue to roll off, albeit more slowly as we move into future quarters and more production on 300-millimeter, we'll continue to see the benefit to gross margins. So I think that the -- well, what you've seen going on is just a preview to what you'll see going on as we look out a little bit further. 
If we look out further in time as to what to expect, I think we'll just tell you to do what we've been doing in the past, which is on a delta revenue that you forecast in your model, that falls through around 70%, 75% on average over time. That'll give you a pretty good way to anticipate what the company's gross margin will stack up best.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So CapEx is going to be noisy in any one quarter so it makes more sense to kind of look at it on a what we think is a trailing 12-month basis. And over the last 12 months, CapEx is running at about 4.5% of our last 12 months revenue. Depreciation ha
componenttext: Okay. So CapEx is going to be noisy in any one quarter so it makes more sense to kind of look at it on a what we think is a trailing 12-month basis. And over the last 12 months, CapEx is running at about 4.5% of our last 12 months revenue. Depreciation has been running about 5.2% for the last 12 months revenue. So obviously, those will converge at some point, but I don't expect those to convert before the end of 2016. They may converge in any 1 quarter, but on that trailing 12-month basis, it'll take a couple of quarters before we see those meet up. And again, remember, our long-term model is to keep our CapEx spending at around 4% of revenue, and that includes the conversion expansion of our 300-millimeter capacity for Analog production.

Sort of comparable to what happened in the March quarter, if I'm not mistaken. So could you just talk about how do you look at OpEx as a percent of sale? And what's driving the higher uptick there? It sounds like -- it looks like it's more R&D than anything in the first half of the year so far.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm not so sure, Amit, if it was higher-than-expected per se, but it was certainly higher than it was last quarter and higher on a year-over-year basis. And you've got a couple of things going on there. Sequentially, you've got 3, 4 months worth of p
componenttext: Yes. I'm not so sure, Amit, if it was higher-than-expected per se, but it was certainly higher than it was last quarter and higher on a year-over-year basis. And you've got a couple of things going on there. Sequentially, you've got 3, 4 months worth of pay and debt increases. So last quarter, we only had 2 month's worth. That's also true year-over-year, by the way. We just got pay and benefit increases. But also importantly on the R&D, as you noted, we have been, for a number of quarters now, reallocated in our internal resources towards more development efforts. So those will be resources that may have been working in manufacturing support or they may have been working in SG&A, and we're redeploying those resources into development activity in R&D, and we expect to continue doing that for a number of quarters to come. And so consequently, you're seeing R&D begin to move up a little bit more than what you might see on the G&A line.
